segment.source: Deploy Windows RE
segment.target: Deploy Windows RE

segment.source: Deploy Windows RE
segment.target: Deploy Windows RE

segment.source: Deploy Windows RE
segment.target: Deploy Windows RE

segment.source: Use these steps to deploy Windows® Recovery Environment (Windows RE) to a new computer, to help end users repair a PC when a system failure occurs.
segment.target: Use these steps to deploy Windows® Recovery Environment (Windows RE) to a new computer, to help end users repair a PC when a system failure occurs.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: To complete this walkthrough, you need the following:
segment.target: To complete this walkthrough, you need the following:

segment.source: A destination computer that has been configured with a Windows RE tools partition, and optionally, a recovery image partition.
segment.target: A destination computer that has been configured with a Windows RE tools partition, and optionally, a recovery image partition.

segment.source: For more information, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.
segment.target: For more information, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.

segment.source: Optional: Customize your recovery media.
segment.target: Optional: Customize your recovery media.

segment.source: For more information, see Customize Windows RE.
segment.target: For more information, see Customize Windows RE.

segment.source: Optional: Customize your recovery media to include custom tools.
segment.target: Optional: Customize your recovery media to include custom tools.

segment.source: For more information, see Add a Custom Tool to the Windows RE Boot Options Menu.
segment.target: For more information, see Add a Custom Tool to the Windows RE Boot Options Menu.

segment.source: Step 1: Deploy Windows RE
segment.target: Step 1: Deploy Windows RE

segment.source: Create a new directory in the Windows RE Tools partition, and then copy your custom Windows RE tools image (Winre.wim) to this directory.
segment.target: Create a new directory in the Windows RE Tools partition, and then copy your custom Windows RE tools image (Winre.wim) to this directory.

segment.source: The following are examples based on your firmware type:
segment.target: The following are examples based on your firmware type:

segment.source: UEFI:
segment.target: UEFI:

segment.source: where T: is the drive letter of your Windows RE Tools partition.
segment.target: where T: is the drive letter of your Windows RE Tools partition.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: BIOS:
segment.target: BIOS:

segment.source: where S: is the system partition.
segment.target: where S: is the system partition.

segment.source: Register your custom Windows RE tools image:
segment.target: Register your custom Windows RE tools image:

segment.source: UEFI:
segment.target: UEFI:

segment.source: where T: is the Windows RE Tools partition.
segment.target: where T: is the Windows RE Tools partition.

segment.source: BIOS
segment.target: BIOS

segment.source: where S: is the System partition.
segment.target: where S: is the System partition.

segment.source: Optional: If you have added a custom tool to your Windows RE boot image, register it so that it will appear on the Boot Options menu:
segment.target: Optional: If you have added a custom tool to your Windows RE boot image, register it so that it will appear on the Boot Options menu:

segment.source: For more information about adding a custom tool, see Add a Custom Tool to the Windows RE Boot Options Menu.
segment.target: For more information about adding a custom tool, see Add a Custom Tool to the Windows RE Boot Options Menu.

segment.source: Optional: Configure a hardware recovery button (or button combination) to run a secondary boot path that contains Windows RE.
segment.target: Optional: Configure a hardware recovery button (or button combination) to run a secondary boot path that contains Windows RE.

segment.source: For more information, see Add a Hardware Recovery Button to Start Windows RE.
segment.target: For more information, see Add a Hardware Recovery Button to Start Windows RE.

segment.source: Step 2: Identify the Recovery Partitions and Hide the Drive Letters
segment.target: Step 2: Identify the Recovery Partitions and Hide the Drive Letters

segment.source: Note If you want to configure push-button reset features for Windows 8 editions, skip this section, and go to the topic: Deploy Push-Button Reset Features.
segment.target: Note If you want to configure push-button reset features for Windows 8 editions, skip this section, and go to the topic: Deploy Push-Button Reset Features.

segment.source: Configure your partitions as recovery partitions, and then conceal the drive letters so the partitions don't appear in common Windows menus, such as File Explorer.
segment.target: Configure your partitions as recovery partitions, and then conceal the drive letters so the partitions don't appear in common Windows menus, such as File Explorer.

segment.source: Prepare a DiskPart script to identify the recovery partitions and to hide drive letters
segment.target: Prepare a DiskPart script to identify the recovery partitions and to hide drive letters

segment.source: In Notepad, create a text file that includes commands to identify and hide the recovery partitions.
segment.target: In Notepad, create a text file that includes commands to identify and hide the recovery partitions.

segment.source: The following examples are based on your firmware type:
segment.target: The following examples are based on your firmware type:

segment.source: UEFI:
segment.target: UEFI:

segment.source: Use the ID: PARTITIONMSFTRECOVERYGUID (de94bba4-06d1-4d40-a16a-bfd50179d6ac) to define the partitions as recovery partitions.
segment.target: Use the ID: PARTITIONMSFTRECOVERYGUID (de94bba4-06d1-4d40-a16a-bfd50179d6ac) to define the partitions as recovery partitions.

segment.source: Use the GPT attributes: 0x8000000000000001 to hide the drive letters and to mark them as required, by using a combination of two attributes: GPTBASICDATAATTRIBUTENODRIVELETTER and GPTATTRIBUTEPLATFORMREQUIRED.
segment.target: Use the GPT attributes: 0x8000000000000001 to hide the drive letters and to mark them as required, by using a combination of two attributes: GPTBASICDATAATTRIBUTENODRIVELETTER and GPTATTRIBUTEPLATFORMREQUIRED.

segment.source: For more information about UEFI hard drive partition attributes, see PARTITIONINFORMATIONGPT structure.
segment.target: For more information about UEFI hard drive partition attributes, see PARTITIONINFORMATIONGPT structure.

segment.source: BIOS:
segment.target: BIOS:

segment.source: Use the attribute: to define the system partition, and use the command to remove the drive letter.
segment.target: Use the attribute: to define the system partition, and use the command to remove the drive letter.

segment.source: Save your completed file as either E:RecoveryHideRecoveryPartitions-UEFI.txt or E:RecoveryHideRecoveryPartitions-BIOS.txt, based on your firmware type.
segment.target: Save your completed file as either E:RecoveryHideRecoveryPartitions-UEFI.txt or E:RecoveryHideRecoveryPartitions-BIOS.txt, based on your firmware type.

segment.source: Identify and hide the drive letters
segment.target: Identify and hide the drive letters

segment.source: Run the diskpart script to identify and hide the recovery partitions:
segment.target: Run the diskpart script to identify and hide the recovery partitions:

segment.source: Where firmware is either UEFI or BIOS.
segment.target: Where firmware is either UEFI or BIOS.

segment.source: Verify that the Windows RE configuration is set correctly
segment.target: Verify that the Windows RE configuration is set correctly

segment.source: Open an administrative command prompt.
segment.target: Open an administrative command prompt.

segment.source: Verify the Windows RE information:
segment.target: Verify the Windows RE information:

segment.source: Verify the following:
segment.target: Verify the following:

segment.source: Windows RE status is enabled.
segment.target: Windows RE status is enabled.

segment.source: Windows RE location is on the correct partition.
segment.target: Windows RE location is on the correct partition.

segment.source: The BCD GUID entry for WinRE is the same as the WinRE GUID entry in the file: reagent.xml.
segment.target: The BCD GUID entry for WinRE is the same as the WinRE GUID entry in the file: reagent.xml.

segment.source: On BIOS-based PCs, this file is on the system partition, at Recovery(GUID).
segment.target: On BIOS-based PCs, this file is on the system partition, at Recovery(GUID).

segment.source: On UEFI-based PCs, this file is on the Windows RE Tools partition, at RecoveryWindowsRE.
segment.target: On UEFI-based PCs, this file is on the Windows RE Tools partition, at RecoveryWindowsRE.

segment.source: WinRE is located in the RecoveryWindowsRE directory
segment.target: WinRE is located in the RecoveryWindowsRE directory
